perturbation.original_text: EFS shall be permitted to offer customers who visit the Websites the option to receive emails from EFS concerning the Merchandise as well as offers by EFS or third-parties with which EFS has an established relationship and which have been approved in advance in writing by Client. Any customers who do not specifically opt-in to receiving email communications from EFS shall be excluded from such communications.
perturbation.changed_text: EFS shall be permitted to offer customers who visit the Websites the option to receive emails from EFS concerning the Merchandise as well as offers by EFS or third-parties with which EFS has an established relationship. Customers may be included in email communications from EFS.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the clause stating 'Any customers who do not specifically opt-in to receiving email communications from EFS shall be excluded from such communications,' the modified text contradicts standard data privacy practices and potentially violates laws like GDPR or CAN-SPAM. The change suggests that EFS can now email customers without explicit consent, conflicting with generally accepted practices and potentially creating legal issues if other sections of the contract mention compliance with data privacy regulations.

perturbation.original_text: All aspects of the Websites and the Catalogs, including, but not limited to, their "look and feel" (including as set forth in Section 1.1(d)(iii) below), use of the Playboy Marks (as defined in Section 7.2), functionality, models to be used and all Merchandise sold therein, shall be subject to Client's prior written approval, which shall not be unreasonably withheld.
perturbation.changed_text: All aspects of the Websites and the Catalogs shall be subject to Client's approval.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mentions the 'look and feel' and refers to Section 1.1(d)(iii) for details on design consistency, along with explicit mention of 'functionality, models, and merchandise' requiring approval. The modified text omits the 'not to be unreasonably withheld' condition and reference to Section 1.1(d)(iii), giving the client full arbitrary power over the website and catalog design without referencing style guides. This makes the enforcement ambiguous, as the specific design, consistency guidelines, and the 'unreasonably withheld' clause have been removed, potentially leading to disagreements over approval rights.

perturbation.original_text: Client agrees that the following marketing activities shall be performed: (a) Client and EFS shall jointly issue a press release following the execution of this Agreement announcing Client's selection of EFS as its end-to-end ecommerce services and platform provider for the Websites; which release shall be subject to Client's final approval not to be unreasonably withheld; (b) Subject to confidentiality obligations hereunder, EFS may prepare and distribute a case study upon launching the Websites with respect to the business arrangement between EFS and Client, subject to Client's prior written approval not to be unreasonably withheld; (c) Subject to confidentiality obligations hereunder, EFS may to prepare and distribute a second case study within three (3) to six (6) months of the launch of the Websites detailing the return on investment resulting from the business relationship between Client and EFS, subject to Client's prior written approval not to be unreasonably withheld;
perturbation.changed_text: Client agrees that the following marketing activities shall be performed: (a) Client and EFS shall jointly issue a press release following the execution of this Agreement announcing Client's selection of EFS as its end-to-end ecommerce services and platform provider for the Websites, subject to Client's final approval; (b) Subject to confidentiality obligations hereunder, EFS may prepare and distribute a case study upon launching the Websites with respect to the business arrangement between EFS and Client, subject to Client's prior written approval; (c) Subject to confidentiality obligations hereunder, EFS may to prepare and distribute a second case study within three (3) to six (6) months of the launch of the Websites detailing the return on investment resulting from the business relationship between Client and EFS, subject to Client's prior written approval;
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'not to be unreasonably withheld' from these marketing approvals, this creates a contradiction. The original text provides a condition to Client's power of approval, providing recourse if Client's actions are considered malicious. The modified text gives the client arbitrary approval rights over the website content, and provides no condition to the Client's approval of website content.
